Minute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge Paul Singh Grewal: Motion Hearing held on 8/18/2015 re 83 MOTION to Compel Further RFP Responses from Defendant California Forensic Medical Group. Plaintiff's Motion to Compel is granted in part. Documents to be produced in response to Request for Document Production Nos. 33 and 34 only to the extent that they relate to facilities identified in the Exhibit Dr. Fithian was describing in his deposition at pages 162 - 165. The court orders 3 additional hours of deposition testimony from Dr. Fithian once production of documents complete, which can include questions about changes in policies and procedures at the Monterey facility and staff practices at the Monterey facility. Depositions to occur no later than 30 days from today's date and documents to be produced no later than 14 days from today's date. case_data.name: Estate of Claypole v. County of San Mateo
case_data.plaintiff_description: The mother of a pretrial detainee who committed suicide while in jail
case_data.summary:
On June 12, 2014, the mother of a pretrial detainee who committed suicide while in jail filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. The plaintiff sued the County of San Mateo, the Mateo County Sheriff, the County of Monterey, the Monterey County Sheriff, the City of Monterey, the Monterey Police, the California Forensic Medical Group, and the Community Hospital of Monterey Peninsula under 42 U.S.C. ยงยง 1983 and 1988, as well as state law. Represented by private counsel, she asked the court for monetary relief, claiming violations of the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution. Specifically, she alleged failures to provide medical care, to protect from harm, and to furnish medical care. She also claimed a deprivation of substantive due process, medical malpractice, negligent supervision, training, hiring, and retention, and wrongful death.

In 2013, the detainee committed suicide while in his administrative segregation cell at the Monterey County Jail by hanging himself with a bed sheet. The detainee had a history of mental illness and had been arrested three days prior for a murder he committed during a bipolar episode. The plaintiff alleged that the Jail's policies and practices for screening, supervising, and treating prisoners at risk for suicide were inadequate. The plaintiff also alleged serious deficiencies in the delivery of mental health care at the Jail. The detainee had been previously detained at the Jail and had not received adequate mental health care.

On October 9, 2014, the District Court granted in part Monterey City's and Monterey County's motions to dismiss with leave to amend to the complaint. The Court also denied the County's motion to strike. On October 28, 2014, the plaintiff filed an amended complaint adding a claim of general negligence and allegations to other claims against Monterey and Monterey County. Then, on November 19, 2014, Judge Labson Freeman denied the Hospital's motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.

On September 22, 2015, Judge Freeman approved the stipulated dismissal of the County and the Sheriff as defendants. Two days later, she approved the stipulated dismissal of the Hospital as a defendant. Presumably these were based on out-of-court settlements.

The case proceeded against the remaining defendants. On January 12, 2016, the court granted summary judgment for a defendant police officer and denied summary judgment for defendant Monterey City. The court found that the plaintiffs had indicated an intention to dismiss the police officer and did not oppose summary judgment as to him. With respect to the City, the court held that there was a dispute as to the issue of whether or not the City "lacks minimally necessary policies and procedures for identifying a detaineeโs mental health issues and responding to those issues appropriately by either transferring the detainee to a mental health facility or transmitting information regarding the detaineeโs mental health to the next custodian."

On February 22, 2016, the court granted partial summary judgment for county defendants and medical defendants.

The parties then progressed toward trial, but on March 28, 2016, the parties indicated they had reached settlement. Accordingly, they moved for voluntary dismissal two days later, which the court granted while retaining jurisdiction over the settlement's enforcement.

The court related this case to Estate of Sandra Vela v. County of Monterey, No. 5:16-cv-02375, on May 12, 2016.

The settlement is not publicly available, though a status report indicates that "[t]he Agreement required payment of all funds by June 24, 2016, as well as the return of Mr. Claypoleโs personal property and handwritten suicide note by that date." There has been no further docket activity since July 2016. The case is now closed.
case_data.summary_short: In 2014, the mother of a pretrial detainee who committed suicide while in jail filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. The plaintiff sued the jail, the hospital, and the communities who interacted with him prior to his suicide for violations of the First and Fourteenth Amendments and other claims including wrongful death. The case settled.

1  INTRODUCTION 
2  1.  On May 4, 2013, 20-year-old Joshua Claypole committed suicide in a 
3  cell at Monterey County Jail by hanging himself from a bed sheet. Three days prior, 
4  Claypole had been arrested for the fatal stabbing of Daniel Garcia Huerta, a taxi 
5  driver, during a bipolar episode. These two tragic deaths should not have 
6  happenedโand would not have happenedโif Defendants in this case had fulfilled 
7  their duties as public safety agencies and followed policies and procedures that are 
8  standard in their fields and required by law.   
9  2.    Defendants are California municipalities, Sheriffsโ departments, 
10  health care providers, and their employees. Each Defendant entity had multiple 
11  contacts with Claypole in the days before his death. Had Defendants followed 
12  standard protocols and training, they would have identified Claypoleโs acute mental 
13  health crisis and risk factors, and intervened to protect him and the public. 
14  However, Defendants did not have the appropriate policies and procedures in place, 
15  and ignored the obvious warning signs.  As a result, two families lost their loved 
16  ones.  
17  3.  The Estate of Joshua Claypole and Claypoleโs mother, Silvia 
18  Guersenzvaig, bring this action for damages against Defendants for violations 
19  arising out of Defendantsโ deliberate indifference and negligence that caused the 
20  needless suffering and death of Joshua Claypole.  
21  JURISDICTION 
22  4.  This Complaint seeks damages for violations of the civil rights, 
23  privileges, and immunities guaranteed by the First and Fourteenth Amendments of 
24  the United States Constitution, pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยงยง 1983 and 1988, and for 
25  violations of California state law.   
26  5.  This Court has jurisdiction over this lawsuit pursuant to 28 U.S.C. 
27  ยงยง 1331 and 1343.

1  FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS  
2  I.  History of Inadequate Mental Health Care in Monterey County Jail 
3  30.  County of Monterey and CFMG have been on notice that their 
4  provision of mental health care to inmates at the Monterey County Jail is 
5  inadequate and results in needless harm since at least 2007, when the Monterey 
6  County Sheriffโs Office and the Monterey County Board of Supervisors hired an 
7  outside consulting firm to perform a needs assessment for the Jail.  
8  31.  The independent assessment was updated in 2011 and found County of 
9  Monterey and CFMGโs policies and practices for screening, supervising, and 
10  treating prisoners at risk for suicide inadequate. (See Exhibit 1.) The 2011 
11  Assessment identified structural and design flaws of cells and dormitories that do 
12  not minimize suicide hazards in the facilities and fail to prevent self-harm. (See 
13  Exhibit 1 at EX.3.)  The Assessment also found that Monterey County Jailโs 
14  physical facilities lack sufficient treatment space and therefore prevent adequate 
15  delivery of medical and mental health care. (Exhibit 1 at EX.3, A.3.) 
16  32.  In addition to the Jailโs structural issues the Assessment found that 
17  chronic understaffing hinders County of Montereyโs ability to provide medical care, 
18  classify and move inmates within the facility, maintain inmate safety and security, 
19  and transport inmates to and from outside agencies. (Exhibit 1 at G.1โG.3, J.2โJ.3.) 
20  In addition, understaffing and overcrowding at the Jail creates what the Assessment 
21  called โan indirect supervision facility,โ which impairs the Jailโs ability to 
22  โrecognize, manage and treatโ mental health issues among the inmate population 
23  (as opposed to direct supervision from experienced physicians and psychologists). 
24  (Id. at EX.3.) 
25  33.  These deficiencies are even more troubling in light of the 
26  Assessmentโs finding that approximately 15โ20% of the Jailโs inmates suffer from 
27  mental health issues. (Exhibit 1 at A.3 n. 4.) 
28  ///

1  34.  The Assessmentโs findings were confirmed in a 2013 draft report by an 
2  expert hired by County of Monterey, Dr. Richard Hayward (โHayward Reportโ).  
3  (See Exhibit 2.) The County tasked Dr. Hayward with evaluating mental health care 
4  at Monterey County Jail in response to a federal class action lawsuit challenging 
5  County of Montereyโs provision of medical and mental health care at the Jail. See 
6  Hernandez v. Cnty. of Monterey, No. 13-cv-2354-PSG (N.D. Cal. filed May 23, 
7  2013). The Hayward Report, dated December 6, 2013, affirmed that understaffing 
8  of mental health professionals led to inadequate mental health care for inmates (see 
9  Exhibit 2 at 5), compounding the 2011 Assessmentโs findings of problems 
10  associated with crowded and space-limited clinics at the Jail. 
11  35.  In addition, the Hayward Report identified other serious deficiencies in 
12  the delivery of mental health care at the Monterey County Jail, including: 
13  a.  Lack of a complete mental health screening process that leads to 
14  inadequate identification of arrestees with a potential for self-harm or a history of 
15  mental disorders. (Exhibit 2 at 2.) 
16  b.  Lack of mental health questions on intake forms that could 
17  adequately log an inmateโs symptoms and treatment history, prior providers, past 
18  diagnoses and medications, and history of self-harm. (Exhibit 2 at 4.) 
19  c.  County of Monterey employs only a total of four mental health 
20  professionals, which the Hayward Report concluded was โinsufficient to meet the 
21  mental health needs of the inmates.โ (Exhibit 2 at 5.)  
22  d.  Lack of mental health care clinicians assigned to the jail on 
23  weekends โresults in insufficient services to mentally ill inmates,โ relevant because 
24  Claypole committed suicide on a Saturday. (Exhibit 2 at 2.) 
25  e.  Inadequate supervision of inmates placed on suicide watch in 
26  designated โSafety Cells,โ including delays of up to an hour or more between 
27  checks of designated inmates who should be monitored twice each thirty minutes. 
28  (Exhibit 2 at 12.)

1  36.  County of Montereyโs failures to timely identify, adequately treat, or 
2  effectively monitor prisoners at risk for suicide have had tragic consequences. 
3  According to the allegations contained in the Hernandez v. County of Monterey 
4  complaint, there had been three completed and over a dozen attempted suicides in 
5  the four years prior to Claypoleโs suicide. According to that complaint, the rate of 
6  completed suicides at the Monterey County Jail is nearly twice the national average 
7  for jail facilities.  
8  37.  Moreover, on April 15, 2013, prior to Joshua Claypoleโs death, County 
9  of Monterey was again specifically put on notice of the serious problems with 
10  mental health treatment in the jail, as well as its disproportionately high suicide 
11  rate, in a letter written by Hernandez class counsel. (See Exhibit 3.)  
12  II.  Joshua Claypoleโs Detentions and Suicide 
13  A.   Claypoleโs Mental Health History 
14  38.  Joshua Claypole was born in Monterey, California, and was raised 
15  primarily in Big Sur, California, by his mother Silvia Guersenzvaig.  
16  39.  Starting in or around his junior year in high school, Claypole began 
17  struggling with substance abuse and exhibiting symptoms of mental illness, 
18  including anxiety, panic disorders, and bipolar disorder. He eventually dropped out 
19  of high school in December of his senior year.  
20  40.  Guersenzvaig sought help for Claypole from numerous mental health 
21  therapists and practitioners from approximately 2010 through 2013.  
22  41.  During this period, Claypole was treated by at least one psychiatrist at 
23  CHOMP, Dr. Marshal Alan Blatt. Dr. Blatt worked with Claypole between March 
24  2012 and August 2012, but abruptly terminated his relationship with Claypole with 
25  no follow up care or referral to another care provider. 
26  42.  In this time, Claypole would fluctuate between normative behavior and 
27  his more agitated, disturbed periods. When on his prescribed medications, he was 
28  funny, loving, creative, and thoughtful, often talking openly about his growth as a

  COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES

1  young adult and the lessons he learned from his past experience and from others. 
2  During periods of instability, however, he struggled with anxiety, aggression, and 
3  substance abuse. This behavior led to two arrests, one for a DUI and vandalism and 
4  the other for minor possession of cocaine. As part of his sentences for these arrests, 
5  Claypole successfully completed several rehabilitation programs. 
6  B.   First Detention in San Mateo County 
7  43.  Joshua Claypoleโs mental health issues came to a head in April 2013. 
8  On April 24, Silvia Guersenzvaig scheduled Claypole to see his treating 
9  psychiatrist, Dr. John R. Donaldson, on May 2. By approximately April 27, 
10  Claypole stopped sleeping, believed he had telepathy, and thought that others were 
11  communicating to him through their thoughts.  
12  44.  Five days before the May 2 appointment with his psychiatrist, Joshua 
13  Claypole experienced a psychotic episode.  On April 28, 2013, while at his 
14  motherโs home, Claypole began acting strangely, exhibited aggressive and paranoid 
15  behavior, and left the home without telling Guersenzvaig where he was going.  
16  45.  Claypole traveled to the home of friends that evening, but did not sleep 
17  the entire night. During the night, he told them he thought the singer of the music 
18  they were listening to was going to come out of the music to kill him.  
19  46.  The next day, Claypole returned to his motherโs home, collected his 
20  belongings, and left without answering her questions about where he was going. He 
21  appeared agitated and paranoid.  
22  47.  Worrying about her sonโs health, Silvia Guersenzvaig called Joshua 
23  Claypoleโs psychiatrist Dr. Donaldson on April 29 and spoke with his office staff 
24  about Claypoleโs behavior. She asked Dr. Donaldsonโs staff to provide further 
25  assistance to Claypole in his upcoming May 2 appointment.  
26  48.  Guersenzvaig called Dr. Donaldsonโs office again on April 30, 2013, 
27  to confirm that Claypole would be receiving assistance and treatment from Dr. 
28  Donaldson at his appointment in two days.

1  49.  After leaving his motherโs home on April 29, records reflect that 
2  Joshua Claypole was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence at 1:00 
3  a.m. on the morning of April 30, 2013, by California Highway Patrol officers in 
4  Redwood City, California. According to San Mateo Sheriffโs Department records, 
5  he was booked and detained at the Maguire Correctional Facility operated by 
6  County of San Mateo at approximately 4:30 a.m., and his car was impounded. A

21  Defendant, jointly and severally, in an amount to be proven at trial; 
22  2.  For damages related to loss of familial relations as to Plaintiff Silvia 
23  Guersenzvaig; 
24  3.  Funeral and burial expenses, and incidental expenses not yet fully 
25  ascertained; 
26  4.  General damages, including damages for physical and emotional pain, 
27  emotional distress, hardship, suffering, shock, worry, anxiety, sleeplessness, illness 
28  and trauma and suffering, the loss of the services, society, care and protection of the 
   
-27- 
  COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES
 
 
 

Case5:14-cv-02730-PSG   Document1   Filed06/12/14   Page30 of 30
 
1  decedent, as well as the loss of financial support and contributions, loss of the 
2  present value of future services and contributions, and loss of economic security;

4  6.  For punitive and exemplary damages against each individually named

10  9.  For such other relief, including injunctive and/or declaratory relief, as

1  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
2  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
3  SAN JOSE DIVISION 
4   
Estate of JOSHUA CLAYPOLE, deceased, 
5  by and through SILVIA GUERSENZVAIG,  Case No.  14-cv-02730-BLF    
 
as Administrator; and SILVIA 
6  GUERSENZVAIG, individually,  ORDER GRANTING DEFENDANT 
HALLโS MOTION FOR SUMMARY 
7  Plaintiffs,  JUDGMENT; DENYING CITY OF 
MONTEREYโS MOTION FOR 
8  v.  SUMMARY JUDGMENT; AND

KRUSE AS A DOE DEFENDANT

[Re:  ECF 97, 108]

a
tr in
uoro 13    This action arises from the suicide of twenty-year old Joshua Claypole (โClaypoleโ) while 
Cfi
 tclaC 14  he was detained in a Monterey County Jail cell.  Plaintiffs are the Estate of Joshua Claypole, by 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  and through Silvia Guersenzvaig (Claypoleโs mother) as Administrator, and Silvia Guersenzvaig 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  individually (โPlaintiffsโ).  Plaintiffs have sued a number of public employees and agencies that 
S de nre 17  had contact with Claypole in the days leading up to his death.  Before the Court are two motions:  
th
intr
UoN 18  (1) a motion for summary judgment, brought by Defendants City of Monterey (โCityโ) and City of 
19  Monterey Police Officer Brent Hall (โHallโ),1 and (2) a motion for leave to substitute City of 
20  Monterey Detective Bryan Kruse (โKruseโ) as a Doe defendant, brought by Plaintiffs.  The Court 
21  has considered the partiesโ briefing, the relevant legal authorities, and the oral argument that was 
22  presented at the hearing on November 12, 2015.  For the reasons discussed below, Defendant 
23  Hallโs motion for summary judgment is GRANTED, Defendant Cityโs motion for summary 
24  judgment is DENIED, and Plaintiffsโ motion for leave to substitute Kruse as a Doe defendant is 
25  DENIED.   
26 
                                                 
1 City of Monterey Police Chief Philip Penko (โPenkoโ), also named as a defendant in this action 
27 
in his official capacity, has not moved for summary judgment.  However, the parties have 
stipulated that the Courtโs ruling with respect to the City shall bind and have the same force and 
28 
effect as to Defendant Penko.  See Stipulation and Order, ECF 145. 

 
1    I.  BACKGROUND2 
2    Prior to the events giving rise to this action, Claypole had been under the care of various 
3  psychiatrists and psychologists.  Guersenzvaig Dep. 46:23-47:6, ECF 105-4.  On the afternoon of 
4  April 28, 2013, Claypole left his home in Big Sur, where he lived with his mother.  Id. 36:8-24.  
5  On April 30, 2013, he was arrested in Redwood City, California, on suspicion of driving under the 
6  influence.  Drug Influence Evaluation, Exh. 85 to Tajsar Decl, ECF 105-3.  Claypoleโs vehicle was 
7  towed and he was taken to the San Mateo County Jail.  Police Report (Bowers), Exh. 45 to Tajsar 
8  Decl., ECF 105-3.  The arresting officer characterized Claypole as confused, with a โblank spacey 
9  stare,โ stated that Claypole did not appear to understand what was happening, and indicated that 
10  Claypole responded incoherently to questions.  Id.    
11    It is not clear when Claypole was released from the San Mateo County Jail, but on May 1, 
12  2013, he appeared at the Community Hospital of Monterey Peninsula (โCHOMPโ), where he 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  previously had received treatment.  Martin Dep. 70:7-20, ECF 105-4; Guersenzvaig Dep. 49:17-
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  50:3, ECF 105-4.  He told the receptionist that he was being chased by someone with a knife.  
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Martin Dep. 70:12-20, ECF 105-4.  CHOMP employees asked Claypole to leave, which he did.  
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Moises Dep. 71:2-72:23, ECF 105-4.  Claypole then went to a nearby Wells Fargo Bank, 
S d nr
ee 17  withdrew money, and asked a bank employee to call him a taxi.  Police Report (Zook), Exh. 12 to 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Tajsar Decl., ECF 105-2.  The bank employee later described Claypole as โout of itโ and โin and 
19  out of consciousness.โ  Id.  Claypole took the taxi to a local rental car company and there he 
20  fatally stabbed the taxi driver.  Police Report (Kruse), Exh. 11 to Tajsar Decl., ECF 105-2.  
21    Shortly thereafter, Seaside Police Department officers stopped Claypole, who was driving 
22  a stolen pickup truck, and detained him pending arrival of City police officers.  Police Report 
23  (Hall), Exh. 9 to Tajsar Decl., ECF 105-2.  City of Monterey Police Officer Hall arrived at the 
24  scene and placed Claypole in the rear of his patrol vehicle.  Id.  Hall transported Claypole to the 
25  City of Monterey Jail for booking.  Id.  The booking process included a screening and assessment 
26  of Claypole conducted by a Police Service Technician (โPSTโ) named Philip Bitter (โBitterโ).  Id.; 
27 
                                                 
28 
2 The background facts contained in this section are undisputed. 
2 

 
1  Booking Information, Exh. 15 to Tajsar Decl., ECF 105-2.  Bitter documented the screening on 
2  the Cityโs booking form, which contains a โmedical screeningโ section listing a series of 34 
3  checkboxes describing various medical issues.  Booking Information, Exh. 15 to Tajsar Decl., 
4  ECF 105-2.   
5    While in Hallโs patrol car, during booking, and after booking while waiting to be 
6  interviewed by a detective, Claypole made a number of spontaneous utterances, including the 
7  following:  โCan you ask for the injection?โ; โI had to do it.โ; โHe told me to do it.  He just 
8  wouldnโt die.โ; โShould I go?โ; and โI should just take the injection.โ  Hall Dep. 62:16-24, 73:21-
9  25, ECF 105-4.  Claypole also asked Hall whether his mother would get his remains, said that he 
10  wanted to die by lethal injection, and said that he wanted to have his body cremated.  Id. 74:8-13. 
11    Claypole was interviewed by City of Monterey Detective Kruse and Sergeant William 
12  Clark.  Police Report (Kruse), Exh. 11 to Tajsar Decl., ECF 105-2; Video Footage of Interview, 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  Exh. 81 to Tajsar Decl. (manually filed).  Claypoleโs Miranda rights were read to him several 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  times because he kept indicating that he did not understand them.  Police Report (Kruse), Exh. 11 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  to Tajsar Decl., ECF 105-2.  Once the interview began, Claypole said that he was trying to decide 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  if he was going to take lethal injection.  Kruse Dep. 181:14-25, ECF 105-4.  Claypole also said he 
S d nr
ee 17  had been hallucinating.  Id. 183:1-9.  Claypole stated that he took medication, including 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  prescriptions for anxiety, and that he had been up for forty-eight hours.  Id. 185:7-11, 191:4-7.   
19  Kruse observed that some of Claypoleโs responses to questions were completely off topic.  Id. 
20  194:2-12.  For example, when Kruse asked Claypole whether he had used controlled substances 
21  recently, he responded, โYouโre telling me that they found the dead bodies?โ  Id.  Kruse elected 
22  not to complete the interview because of the difficulty getting straight answers out of Claypole, 
23  which Kruse thought might be due to the influence of a controlled substance.  Id. 132:3-14.  
24    Kruse and City of Monterey Officer Jeremiah Ruttschow (โRuttschowโ) transported 
25  Claypole to CHOMP for a blood draw.  Kruse Dep. 133:16-134:6, ECF 105-4.  While at CHOMP, 
26  Claypole became upset and wanted to see a manager.  Id. 137:5-24.  He refused to have blood 
27  drawn, stating that the officers were trying to kill him.  Id. 138:1-23.  He also resisted efforts to get 
28  him back to the squad car.  Id. 138:24-139:8.  Kruse and Ruttschow physically removed Claypole 
3 

 
1  from CHOMP, placed him in the squad car, and transported him back to the City jail.  Id. 139:5- 8; 
2  Ruttschow Dep. 168:9-18, ECF 105-4.  
3    At approximately 9:00 p.m. that evening, Ruttschow transported Claypole to Monterey 
4  County Jail.  Ruttschow Dep. 169:10-23, ECF 105-4.  When an arresting agency transfers a 
5  suspect to the Monterey County Jail, the arresting agency completes and provides a โPre-Booking 
6  Sheetโ3 to the County.  Jackson Dep. 70:24-72:21, ECF 105-4.  The Pre-Booking Sheet for 
7  Claypole was completed by PST Bitter, who signed the sheet โBitter for Kruse.โ  Pre-Booking 
8  Sheet, Exh. 6 to Tajsar Decl., ECF 105-3.  Out of the listed descriptors for demeanor, Bitter 
9  circled โcalm,โ and out of the listed descriptors for speech, Bitter circled โslow.โ  Id.  The Pre-
10  Booking Sheet did not describe any of Claypoleโs aberrant behavior and did not indicate that he 
11  might be suffering from a mental health issue.  Id.   
12    Claypole was screened when he arrived at the Monterey County Jail.  Intake Health 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  Screening, Exh. 32 to Tajsar Decl., ECF 105-3.  The intake health screening form completed that 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  night has the โnoโ box checked for the questions:  โDoes behavior suggest a danger to self or 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  others?โ and โDoes inmate appear to be under the influence of drugs or alcohol?โ  Id.  The box on 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  the intake health screening form for โpsychiatric problemsโ is not checked.  Id.  
S d nr
ee 17    After Claypole was booked into the Monterey County Jail, he met with his defense 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  attorney, John Klopfenstein (โKlopfensteinโ).  Bass Dep. 188:2-9, Defs.โ Exh. N, ECF 98-10; 
19  McGregor Memo., Defs.โ Exh. Q, ECF 98-11.  Following that meeting, Klopfenstein told jail 
20  personnel that Claypole had stated that he wanted to kill himself.  McGregor Memo., Defs.โ Exh. 
21  Q, ECF 98-11.  Claypole was placed in a safety cell on suicide watch that night.  Kaye Dep. 83:7-
22  10, 126:10-127:25, Defs.โ Exh. O, ECF 98-10.  He was taken off suicide watch the following 
23  morning, on May 2, 2013.  Id. 98:18-21, 137:12-138:21.  Claypole was placed on suicide watch a 
24  second time on May 3, 2013.  Safety Cell Log, Defs.โ Exh. S, ECF 98-11.  He again was removed 
25  from suicide watch on May 4, 2013.  Interrog. Responses, Defs.โ Exh. T, ECF 98-11.  Later on 
26  May 4, Claypole was discovered to have hanged himself in his cell.  Inmate Injury Report, Defs.โ 
27 
                                                 
3 Also referred to in the papers as a โPre-Booking Form.โ 
28 
 
4 

 
1  Exh. U, ECF 98-11. 
2    Plaintiffsโ operative first amended complaint (โFACโ) asserts the following claims:  (1) a ยง 
3  19834 claim for deliberate indifference to serious medical and mental health needs in violation of 
4  the Fourteenth Amendment ; (2) a ยง 1983 claim for failure to protect from harm in violation of the 
5  Fourteenth Amendment; (3) a ยง 1983 claim for deprivation of substantive due process in violation 
6  of the First and Fourteenth Amendments (causing loss of parent/child relationship); (4) a 
7  professional negligence/medical malpractice claim under California law; (5) failure to furnish 
8  medical care under California law; (6) negligent supervision, training, hiring, and retention under 
9  California law; and (7) wrongful death under California Code of Civil Procedure ยง 377.60.   
10    The City and Officer Hall are defendants to the second claim for failure to protect from 
11  harm in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment and the third claim for deprivation of substantive 
12  due process under the Fourteenth Amendment.  They seek summary judgment as to both claims.  
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  In their opposition to the City Defendantsโ motion for summary judgment, Plaintiffs indicate that 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  they intend to dismiss Hall based upon information gained in discovery.  Plaintiffs instead wish to 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  seek individual liability against City of Monterey Detective Kruse, and they have filed a motion 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  seeking leave to substitute Kruse as a Doe defendant.  That motion is opposed by the City 
S d nr
ee 17  Defendants.   
th
intr
Uo
N 18    II.  CITY DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
19    A.  Legal Standard 
20    โA party is entitled to summary judgment if the โmovant shows that there is no genuine 
21  dispute as to any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.โโ  City of 
22  Pomona v. SQM North America Corp., 750 F.3d 1036, 1049 (9th Cir. 2014) (quoting Fed. R. Civ. 
23  P. 56(a)).  โThe moving party initially bears the burden of proving the absence of a genuine issue 
24  of material fact.โ  In re Oracle Corp. Sec. Litig., 627 F.3d 376, 387 (9th Cir. 2010) (citing Celotex 
25  Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 323 (1986)).  โWhere the non-moving party bears the burden of 
26  proof at trial, the moving party need only prove that there is an absence of evidence to support the 
27 
                                                 
28 
4 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983. 
5 

 
1  non-moving partyโs case.โ  Id. โWhere the moving party meets that burden, the burden then shifts 
2  to the non-moving party to designate specific facts demonstrating the existence of genuine issues 
3  for trial.โ  Id.  โ[T]he non-moving party must come forth with evidence from which a jury could 
4  reasonably render a verdict in the non-moving partyโs favor.โ  Id.  โThe court must view the 
5  evidence in the light most favorable to the nonmovant and draw all reasonable inferences in the 
6  nonmovantโs favor.โ  City of Pomona, 750 F.3d at 1049.  โโWhere the record taken as a whole 
7  could not lead a rational trier of fact to find for the nonmoving party, there is no genuine issue for 
8  trial.โโ  Id. (quoting Matsushita Elec. Indus. Co., Ltd. v. Zenith Radio Corp., 475 U.S. 574, 587  
9  (1986)). 
10    B.  Officer Brent Hall 
11    As noted above, Plaintiffs have indicated their intention to dismiss Hall from this case.  
12  Plaintiffs have not offered any substantive opposition to Hallโs motion for summary judgment.  
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  Accordingly, the motion for summary judgment is GRANTED as to Hall.   
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    C.  City of Monterey 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15    โA government entity may not be held liable under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, unless a policy, 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  practice, or custom of the entity can be shown to be a moving force behind a violation of 
S d nr
ee 17  constitutional rights.โ  Dougherty v. City of Covina, 654 F.3d 892, 900 (9th Cir. 2011) (citing 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Monell v. Depโt of Soc. Servs. of the City of New York, 436 U.S. 658 (1978)).  โMunicipal liability 
19  may be established on account of the cityโs deliberate acts or omissions.โ  Conn v. City of Reno, 
20  591 F.3d 1081, 1102 (9th Cir. 2009), vacated, 131 S. Ct. 1812 (2011), reinstated in part and 
21  vacated in part, 658 F.3d 897 (9th Cir. 2011); see also Long v. Cnty. of Los Angeles, 442 F.3d 
22  1178 (9th Cir. 2006) (โA policy can be one of action or inaction.โ).  โMunicipal liability for a 
23  failure to act requires a showing โ(1) that a [municipal] employee violated the plaintiffโs 
24  constitutional rights; (2) that the [municipality] has customs or policies that amount to deliberate 
25  indifference; and (3) that these customs or policies were the moving force behind the employeeโs 
26  violation of constitutional rights.โโ  Conn, 591 F.3d at 1102 (quoting Long, 442 F.3d at 1186) 
27  (alterations in original).   
28    Claim 2 asserts that the City and its officers failed to protect Claypole from harm in 
6 

 
1  violation of the Fourteenth Amendment, see FAC ยถ 93, and Claim 3 asserts that Claypoleโs 
2  resulting death deprived Guersenzvaig of her liberty interest in the parent-child relationship in 
3  violation of her substantive due process rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, see FAC ยถ 99.  
4  The City seeks summary judgment on both claims, contending that no reasonable trier of fact 
5  could find for Plaintiffs on Claim 2, and that Claim 3 is wholly dependent on Claim 2.   
6      1.  Claim 2 โ Failure to Protect in Violation of Fourteenth Amendment 
7    The Court thus begins its analysis with Claim 2, which alleges that the City and its officers 
8  โfailed to take necessary precautions to ensure that Claypole would not harm himself or others 
9  after he communicated clearly suicidal thoughts to Monterey Police Department officersโ; โfailed 
10  to create minimally necessary policies and procedures for ensuring that other entities and 
11  municipalities were informed of suicide risks among Monterey Police Department arrestees who 
12  are transferred from their custodyโ; and โfailed to adequately train and supervise officers to protect 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  arrestees from harm.โ  FAC ยถ 93.  At the hearing, Plaintiffsโ counsel clarified that Plaintiffsโ 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Fourteenth Amendment claim against the City is based upon their contention that the City lacks 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  minimally necessary policies and procedures for identifying a detaineeโs mental health issues and 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  responding to those issues appropriately by either transferring the detainee to a mental health 
S d nr
ee 17  facility or transmitting information regarding the detaineeโs mental health to the next custodian. 
th
intr
Uo
N 18    Applying the legal standard set forth above, the City may be liable on Claim 2 if (1) a City 
19  employee violated Claypoleโs rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, (2) the City has customs or 
20  policies that amount to deliberate indifference, and (3) those customs or policies were the moving 
21  force behind the City employeeโs violation of Claypoleโs Fourteenth Amendment rights. 
22        a.  City Employeesโ Violation of Fourteenth Amendment Rights 
23    โThe Eighth Amendment protects inmates from cruel and unusual punishment, which 
24  includes the denial of medical care.โ  Conn, 591 F.3d at 1094.  โPretrial detainees, by contrast, are 
25  protected under the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.โ  Id.  Courts have 
26  borrowed from the Eighth Amendment jurisprudence to determine the minimum standard of care 
27  that must be given to a pretrial detainee under the Fourteenth Amendment.  Id.; Simmons v. 
28  Navajo Cnty., 609 F.3d 1011, 1017 (9th Cir. 2010) (โAlthough the Fourteenth Amendmentโs Due 
7 

 
1  Process Clause, rather than the Eighth Amendmentโs protection against cruel and unusual 
2  punishment, applies to pretrial detainees, we apply the same standards in both cases.โ) (internal 
3  citation omitted); Gibson v. Cnty. of Washoe, 290 F.3d 1175, 1187 (9th Cir. 2002) (โWith regard 
4  to medical needs, the due process clause imposes, at minimum, the same duty as the Eighth 
5  Amendment imposes.โ).   
6    โThe Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments both guarantee that inmates and detainees 
7  receive constitutionally adequate medical and mental health care.โ  Conn, 591 F.3d at 1094.  โAn 
8  officialโs deliberate indifference to a substantial risk of serious harm to an inmate โ including the 
9  deprivation of a serious medical need โ violates the Eighth Amendment, and a fortiori, the 
10  Fourteenth Amendment.โ  Id.; see also Gibson, 290 F.3d at 1187 (โpersons in custody have the 
11  established right to not have officials remain deliberately indifferent to their serious medical 
12  needsโ) (quotation marks, citation, and brackets omitted).  
 
a
tr in
uoro 13    To set forth a constitutional claim under the Eighth Amendment โ or, here, under the 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Fourteenth Amendment โ a plaintiff must show (1) a serious medical need and (2) that an 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  officialโs response to the need was deliberately indifferent.  Conn, 591 F.3d  at 1095; see also 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Simmons, 609 F.3d at 1017 (โWe have long analyzed claims that correction facility officials 
S d nr
ee 17  violated pretrial detaineesโ constitutional rights by failing to address their medical needs 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  (including suicide prevention) under a deliberate indifference standard.โ) (internal quotation marks 
19  and citation omitted).  โThe second prong requires both (a) a purposeful act or failure to respond to 
20  a prisonerโs pain or possible medical need and (b) harm caused by the indifference.โ  Conn, 591 
21  F.3d  at 1095.  Thus to make out a claim of deliberate indifference, a plaintiff must establish 
22  โserious medical need, indifference to that need, and harm caused by that indifference.โ  Id.   
23    Before turning the partiesโ evidence on these three elements, the Court briefly addresses 
24  the Cityโs argument that it cannot be liable under a โspecial relationshipโ theory because the 
25  special relationship created by the Cityโs custody of Claypole terminated when the City transferred 
26  custody of Claypole to Monterey County.  See Defs.โ Br. at 6-7, ECF 97.  The City acknowledges 
27  that a special relationship existed during the period in which the City had custody of Claypole.  
28  See DeShaney v. Winnebago Cnty. Depโt of Social Servs., 489 U.S. 189, 198 (1989) (recognizing 
8 

 
1  that although the Due Process clause generally does not confer an affirmative right to 
2  governmental aid, โthe Eighth Amendmentโs prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment, 
3  made applicable to the States through the Fourteenth Amendmentโs Due Process Clause, requires 
4  the State to provide adequate medical care to incarcerated prisonersโ) (internal citation omitted).  
5  The City argues, however, that City officersโ alleged knowledge that Claypole was a suicide risk 
6  did not create a continuing relationship after the City transferred custody to Monterey County.  
7  Plaintiffs do not assert the existence of a continuing relationship following transfer of Claypoleโs 
8  custody.  See Pls.โ Opp. at 17-18, ECF 105.  Plaintiffsโ theory of liability is that the City and its 
9  officers violated Claypoleโs Fourteenth Amendment rights by their deliberate indifference to his 
10  serious medical need while he was in the Cityโs custody.  That theory properly is evaluated under 
11  the standards set forth in Conn, Simmons, and Gibson, and discussed in detail below.    
12          i.  Serious Medical Need 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13    A detainee has โa serious medical need if the failure to treat the condition could result in 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  further significant injury or the unnecessary and wanton infliction of pain.โ  Conn, 591 F.3d at 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  1095 (internal quotation marks and citation omitted).  โA heightened suicide risk or an attempted 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  suicide is a serious medical need.โ  Id.; see also Simmons, 609 F.3d at 1018 (โ[W]e have 
S d nr
ee 17  previously recognized that a heightened suicide risk can present a serious medical need.โ).  
th
intr
Uo
N 18    The City argues that Claypole did not have a serious medical need while he was in the 
19  Cityโs custody.  See Defs.โ Reply at 4-6, ECF 107.  However, the Court has no difficulty 
20  concluding that a reasonable jury could find to the contrary.  The evidence demonstrates that a 
21  reasonable inference could be drawn by the jury that Claypole was in the midst of a mental health

25    The Ninth Circuit has held that a lack of affirmative policies or procedures to guide 
26  employees can amount to deliberate indifference even when other general policies are in place.  
27  See, e.g., Long, 442 F.3d at 1189; Gibson, 290 F.3d at 1195-96.  โ[W]hen the need to remedy the 
28  omission โis so obvious, and the inadequacy is so likely to result in the violation of constitutional 
16 

 
1  rights, . . . the policymakers of the city can reasonably be said to have been deliberately indifferent 
2  to the need.โโ  Gibson, 290 F.3d at 1195 (quoting City of Canton v. Harris, 489 U.S. 378, 390 
3  (1989)).  โThe need to act may be obvious because any reasonable person would recognize the 
4  need.โ  Id.  โUnlike the deliberate indifference standard used to determine if a violation of a 
5  detaineeโs rights to receive medical care took place, this standard does not contain a subjective 
6  component.โ  Id.  โ[T]he Canton standard assigns liability even when a municipality has 
7  constructive notice that it needs to remedy its omissions in order to avoid violations of 
8  constitutional rights.โ  Id. at 1187 n.8; see also Connick v. Thompson, 563 U.S. 51, 1360 (2011) 
9  (holding that in the context of failure to train, a city may be deemed deliberately indifferent if its 
10  policymakers choose to retain a program despite โactual or constructive notice that a particular

6  policy amounted to deliberate indifference must go to a jury, noting that โ[w]hen policymakers 
7  know that their medical staff members will encounter those with urgent mental health needs yet 
8  fail to provide for the identification of those needs, it is obvious that a constitutional violation 
9  could well result.โ  Id. at 1196. 
10    Applying that rationale to the present case, the Court concludes that there are triable issues 
11  which must be resolved by a jury as to whether the Cityโs failure to implement more rigorous 
12  mental health screening, or to require transmission of detaineesโ mental health information to the 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  next custodian, amounted to deliberate indifference.  
Cfi
 tla
cC 14        c.  Policy as Moving Force 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15    โFor a policy to be the moving force behind the deprivation of a constitutional right, the 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  identified deficiency in the policy must be โclosely related to the ultimate injury.โโ  Long, 442 F.3d 
S d nr
ee 17  at 1190 (quoting Gibson, 290 F.3d at 1196).  โThe plaintiffโs burden is to establish that the injury 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  would have been avoided had proper policies been implemented.โ  Id. (internal quotation marks 
19  and citation omitted).  The City does not argue this element of Plaintiffsโ claim.       
20      2.  Claim 3 โ Loss of Parent/Child Relationship in Violation of Fourteenth 
21        Amendment 
22    Parents may assert a Fourteenth Amendment substantive due process claim if they are 
23  deprived of their liberty interest in the companionship of their child through official conduct.  
24  Lemire v. Cal. Depโt of Corr. and Rehab., 726 F.3d 1062, 1075 (9th Cir. 2013).  โOnly official 
25  conduct that shocks the conscience is cognizable as a due process violation.โ  Id. (internal 
26  quotation marks and citation omitted).  โJust as the deliberate indifference of prison officials may 
27  support Eighth Amendment liability, such indifference may also rise to the conscience-shocking 
28  level required for substantive due process violation.โ  Id. (internal quotation marks and citation 
19 

 
1  omitted).  โA prison officialโs deliberately indifferent conduct will generally shock the conscience 
2  so as long as the prison official had time to deliberate before acting or failing to act in a 
3  deliberately indifferent manner.โ  Id. (internal quotation marks and citation omitted). 
4    The City seeks summary judgment on Claim 3 based upon its assertion that it is entitled to 
5  summary judgment on Plaintiffsโ deliberate indifference claim set forth in Claim 2.  As discussed 
6  above, triable issues of material fact preclude summary judgment on Claim 2.  As a result, the City 
7  has failed to establish that it is entitled to summary judgment on Claim 3.     
8    III.  PLAINTIFFSโ MOTION TO SUBSTITUTE DETECTIVE KRUSE AS DOE 
9    Although Plaintiffs have elected not to pursue their ยง 1983 claims against Officer Hall, 
10  they wish to substitute Detective Kruse as a Doe defendant so that they may pursue ยง 1983 claims 
11  against him individually.  As discussed below, substitution of a new defendant in place of a Doe 
12  defendant is a state law concept that permits the claims against the new defendant to โrelate backโ 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  to the filing of the original complaint.       
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    A.  Relation Back Under State Law 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15    Where, as here, state law provides the applicable statute of limitations,7 an amended 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  complaint may relate back to the filing of the original complaint if it satisfies either state or federal 
S d nr
ee 17  law on relation back.  Butler v. Natโl Cmty. Renaissance of Cal., 766 F.3d 1191, 1200 (9th Cir. 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  2014).  Under California law, โ[t]he general rule is that an amended complaint that adds a new 
19  defendant does not relate back to the date of filing the original complaint and the statute of 
20  limitations is applied as of the date the amended complaint is filed, not the date the original 
21  complaint is filed.โ  Woo v. Sup. Ct., 75 Cal. App. 4th 169, 176 (1999); see also Butler, 766 F.3d 
22  at 1201.  An exception to that general rule permits a plaintiff to substitute a new defendant for a 
23  fictitious Doe defendant named in the original complaint.  Woo, 75 Cal. App. 4th at 176.  
24  However, in order to come under that exception the plaintiff must have been โgenuinely ignorantโ 
25  of the new defendantโs identity at the time the plaintiff filed the original complaint.  Id. at 177.   
26 
                                                 
27 
7 Because ยง 1983 does not contain its own statute of limitations, claims brought under that statute 
are governed by Californiaโs statute of limitations for personal injury claims, which is two years.  
28 
Butler v. Natโl Cmty. Renaissance of Cal., 766 F.3d 1191, 1198 (9th Cir. 2014). 
20 

 
1    At the hearing, Plaintiffsโ counsel argued that Plaintiffs tried to act responsibly by naming 
2  only Hall in their initial complaint and refraining from a scattershot approach of naming all 
3  officers mentioned in the police reports.  Counsel asserted that they were not convinced that Kruse 
4  was a proper defendant until they deposed him in August 2015.  While it appreciates the motive 
5  articulated by counsel, the Court is at a loss to understand why counsel did not feel that Plaintiffs 
6  had enough information to assert a claim against Kruse based upon his police report, which 
7  Plaintiffs admittedly had before filing their original complaint in June 2014.  Kruseโs report, 
8  which is seventeen pages long, provides extensive detail regarding his interaction with Claypole 
9  on May 1, including the highlights of his interview with Claypole and an account of his trip to the 
10  hospital with Claypole for the ultimately unsuccessful blood draw.  That report contained all the 
11  information necessary to identify Kruse and his role in the case.  
12    The Court notes that Plaintiffsโ counsel acknowledged at the hearing that Plaintiffs 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  received the video footage of Kruseโs custodial interview of Claypole in March 2015.  As 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  discussed above, that footage is among the most compelling evidence in the record that Claypole 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  was having a mental health crisis.  Yet Plaintiffs waited more than six more months after receiving 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  the video footage to file the present motion.  The fact that Plaintiffs waited so long even after 
S d nr
ee 17  receiving the video footage undermines their representation that their delay in seeking to add 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Kruse was caused by their ignorance of facts sufficient to put them on notice of their claim against 
19  him.   
20    Because Plaintiffs had Kruseโs police report when they filed the original complaint, they 
21  do not satisfy the requirements for relation back under state law.  See Butler, 766 F.3d at 1202 
22  (plaintiffโs addition of new defendants did not relate back under California law because plaintiff 
23  โwas not ignorantโ of their names or identities at the time the original complaint was filed). 
24    B.  Relation Back Under Federal Law 
25    Nor do Plaintiffs satisfy the requirements for relation back under federal law, which is set 
26  forth in Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15(c).  Under that rule, an amended pleading relates back 
27  to the filing of the original complaint if the following requirements are met:  โ(1) the basic claim 
28  must have arisen out of the conduct set forth in the original pleading; (2) the party to be brought in 
21 

 
1  must have received such notice that it will not be prejudiced in maintaining its defense; (3) that 
2  party must or should have known that, but for a mistake concerning identity, the action would 
3  have been brought against it.โ  Butler, 766 F.3d at 1191.  Relation back under the federal rule thus 
4  โdepends on what the party to be added knew or should have known, not on the amending partyโs 
5  knowledge or its timeliness in seeking to amend the pleading.โ  Krupski v. Costa Crociere, 560 
6  U.S. 538, 541 (2010).   
7    This action was filed in June 2014, a year and a half before Plaintiffs filed the present 
8  motion.  Kruse states in a declaration that he became aware of the lawsuit, and the fact that Officer 
9  Hall had been named as an individual defendant, in June 2014.  Kruse Decl. ยถ 6, ECF 114-1.  
10  Kruse โtook a keen interestโ in the lawsuit because he was the detective assigned to investigate the 
11  murder.  Id.  Kruse knew that he had prepared a lengthy police report setting forth his interactions 
12  with Claypole and his involvement in the investigation.  Id. ยถ 9.  Kruse thought that Plaintiffs 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  could have and would have named him in the initial complaint had they wished to pursue claims 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  against him.  Id.  Plaintiffs have not presented evidence suggesting that Kruse had any reason to 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  believe that he would have been named as a defendant in the original complaint โbut for a mistake 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  concerning identity.โ   
S d nr
ee 17    C.  Amendment Under Rule 15(a) 
th
intr
Uo
N 18    In the event that the Court denies their request to substitute Kruse as a Doe defendant, 
19  Plaintiffs request leave to amend to add Kruse as a defendant under Federal Rule of Civil 
20  Procedure 15(a).  While a court should freely grant leave to amend when justice requires, Fed. R. 
21  Civ. P. 15(a)(2), leave need not be granted where amendment:  โ(1) prejudices the opposing party; 
22  (2) is sought in bad faith; (3) produces an undue delay in litigation; or (4) is futile.โ 
23  AmerisourceBergen Corp. v. Dialysist West, Inc., 465 F.3d 946, 951 (9th Cir. 2006) (citation 
24  omitted).  The City argues that amendment to add Kruse would be futile because, absent relation 
25  back, Plaintiffsโ proposed claims against Kruse are time-barred.   
26    Plaintiffsโ proposed ยง 1983 claims are subject to a two-year statute of limitations.  See 
27  Butler, 766 F.3d at 1198.  Claypole hanged himself on May 4, 2013.  If Plaintiffsโ ยง 1983 claims 
28  against Kruse accrued on that date, the statute of limitations expired on May 4, 2015.  Plaintiffs 
22 

 
1  assert that their claims against Kruse did not accrue until โthe breadth of his involvement in 
2  Claypoleโs arrest and custody were revealed during discovery.โ  Pls.โ Reply at 4, ECF 115.  
3  Plaintiffs rely on Lukovsky, Wallace, Kubrick, and Davis, ignoring that in each of those cases the 
4  court found that the plaintiffโs claims were time-barred.   
5    Plaintiffs state accurately that federal law determines when a civil rights claim accrues.  
6  See Wallace v. Kato, 549 U.S. 384, 388 (2007).  However, Plaintiffs fail to identify the actual 
7  standards set forth by the Supreme Court and the Ninth Circuit.  Specifically, Plaintiffs ignore the 
8  requirement of diligence in pursuing discovery of fault and instead rely on โstray remarksโ from 
9  the cited cases which do not address the issue at hand.  See Lukovsky v. City & Cnty. of San 
10  Francisco, 535 F.3d 1044, 1051 (9th Cir. 2008). 
11    Plaintiffs rely on United States v. Kubrick, 444 U.S. 111 (1979), a medical malpractice 
12  case arising under the Federal Tort Claims Act in which the Supreme Court determined that: 
 
a
tr in  
uoro 13  We thus cannot hold that Congress intended that โaccrualโ of a claim must await 
Cfi
 tla awareness by the plaintiff that his injury was negligently inflicted.  A plaintiff such 
ciC 14  as Kubrick, armed with the facts about the harm done to him, can protect himself 
rts fo by seeking advice in the medical and legal community.  To excuse him from 
iD tc 15  promptly doing so by postponing the accrual of his claim would undermine the 
 sir
et purpose of the limitations statute, which is to require the reasonably diligent 
tatsiD 16  presentation of tort claims against the Government. 
S d nr
ee 17  Id. at 123 (footnote omitted).   
th
intr
Uo
N 18    In Davis v. United States, 642 F.2d 328 (9th Cir. 1981), the Ninth Circuit applied Kubrick 
19  to bar the action as untimely, holding that โ[i]n the absence of fraudulent concealment it is 
20  plaintiffโs burden, within the statutory period, to determine whether and whom to sue.  Kubrick 
21  makes this plain.โ  Id. at 331. 
22    In Lukovsky, the Ninth Circuit affirmed dismissal of an employment discrimination action, 
23  holding that โa claim accrues under federal law when the plaintiff knows or has reason to know of 
24  the actual injury.โ  Lukovsky, 535 F.3d at 1048.  Nothing in the Lukovsky decision supports 
25  Plaintiffsโ contention that there would be a separate accrual date for each potential individual 
26  defendant where it was known on the date of the injury โ termination in the Lukovsky case โ that 
27  the employer was the cause of the injury.  Moreover, to allow such a floating accrual date would 
28  fly in the face of the Supreme Courtโs admonition:  โWere it otherwise, the statute would begin to 
23 

 
1  run only after a plaintiff became satisfied that he had been harmed enough, placing the supposed 
2  statute of repose in the sole hands of the party seeking relief.โ  Wallace, 549 U.S. at 391. 
3    Entirely absent from the proposed amended complaint and Plaintiffsโ argument is any 
4  showing of diligence on their part in discovering Kruseโs role in the case or any concealment by 
5  the City.  Plaintiffsโ reliance on the timing of discovery responses is insufficient.  No explanation 
6  is offered why Plaintiffs delayed until late 2014 to seek written discovery and until August 2015 to 
7  depose Kruse.  The evidence shows that within a few days of her sonโs death, Ms. Guersenzvaig 
8  spoke to Kruse and learned that he was investigating the murder Claypole was alleged to have 
9  committed.  Police Report (Kruse) at 13-15, Defs.โ Exh. A, ECF 114-3.  As noted above, Plaintiffs 
10  also had obtained a copy of Kruseโs police report, documenting Kruseโs substantial contact with 
11  Claypole, prior to filing the original complaint.  Under these circumstances there is no evidence of 
12  diligence sufficient to delay the accrual of Plaintiffsโ claims against Kruse.  
 
a
tr in
uoro 13    Because Plaintiffsโ proposed claims against Kruse are time-barred and thus futile, 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  amendment is not warranted under Rule 15(a). 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15    D.  Conclusion 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16    Plaintiffsโ proposed ยง 1983 claims against Kruse are time-barred and Plaintiffs do not 
S d nr
ee 17  satisfy the requirements for relation back under either state or federal law.  Accordingly, their 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  motion to substitute Kruse as a Doe defendant or, alternatively, for leave to amend the complaint 
19  is DENIED. 
20    V.  ORDER 
21    For the foregoing reasons, IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that: 
22    (1)  Defendant Hallโs motion for summary judgment is GRANTED; 
23    (2)  Defendant City of Montereyโs motion for summary judgment is DENIED; and 
24    (3)  Plaintiffsโ motion for leave to substitute Detective Bryan Kruse as a Doe defendant 
25      is DENIED. 
26   
27  Dated:  January 12, 2016          ______________________________________ 
BETH LABSON FREEMAN 
28  United States District Judge

documents.title: Order Granting in Part County Defendants' Motion for Summary Judgment and Denying Plaintiffs' Corss-Motion; and Granting in Part Medical Defendants' motion for Summary Judgment and Denying Plaintiffs' Cross-Motion
documents.text:
1   
2  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
3  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
4  SAN JOSE DIVISION 
5   
ESTATE OF JOSHUA CLAYPOLE, et al., 
6  Case No.  14-cv-02730-BLF    
Plaintiffs,   
7   
v.  ORDER GRANTING IN PART 
8    COUNTY DEFENDANTSโ MOTION 
COUNTY OF MONTEREY, et al.,  FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT AND 
9  DENYING PLAINTIFFSโ CROSS-
Defendants.  MOTION; AND GRANTING IN PART 
10  MEDICAL DEFENDANTSโ MOTION 
  FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT AND 
11  DENYING PLAINTIFFSโ CROSS-
  MOTION 
12 
 
a
tr in   [Re:  ECF 124, 141, 142, 146] 
uoro 13       
Cfi
 tla  
ciC 14   
rts fo
iD tc 15    This action follows the tragic deaths of two people, one of whom was Plaintiff Silvia 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Guersenzvaigโs son, Joshua Claypole.  Claypole, a young man with a history of mental health 
S d nr
ee 17  issues, inexplicably killed a taxi driver named Daniel Garcia Huerta and then days later hanged 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  himself in a Monterey County jail cell while detained for Huertaโs murder.  Guersenzvaig filed 
19  this action individually and on behalf of Claypoleโs estate, asserting that jail personnel and others 
20  were deliberately indifferent to Claypoleโs serious medical needs in violation of his federal 
21  constitutional rights and breached duties owed to him under state law.   
22    Two sets of cross-motions for summary judgment are before the Court.  Defendants 
23  Monterey County, Monterey County Sheriff Scott Miller, and Sergeant Erika Kaye โ all involved 
24  in the operation of the jail โ seek summary judgment against Plaintiffs, who in turn seek partial 
25  summary judgment against them.  Additionally, Defendants Taylor Fithian and California 
26  Forensic Medical Group (โMedical Defendantsโ) โ the doctor and medical group who provide 
27  medical care at the jail โ seek partial summary judgment against Plaintiffs, who in turn seek partial 
28  summary judgment against them.   

 
1    For the reasons discussed below, the County Defendantsโ motion is GRANTED IN PART, 
2  Plaintiffsโ cross-motion against the County Defendants is DENIED, the Medical Defendantsโ 
3  motion is GRANTED IN PART, and Plaintiffsโ cross-motion against the Medical Defendants is 
4  DENIED.     
5    I.  BACKGROUND 
6    The chronology of events leading up to Claypoleโs death is largely undisputed.1  On the 
7  afternoon of Wednesday, May 1, 2013, Claypole murdered Huerta for unknown reasons.  City of 
8  Monterey police officers took him into custody shortly afterward, held him for several hours, and 
9  then transported him to the Monterey County jail.  Claypole was taken into custody at the jail at 
10  approximately 9:00 p.m. on Wednesday night.  He was placed in a single cell, pending review.  
11    First Placement on Suicide Watch (Wednesday, May 1)  
12    At approximately 10:15 p.m. that night, Claypole met with his attorney, who thereafter told 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  a jail employee named Candice McGregor that Claypole had said he wanted to kill himself.  
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  McGregor called Defendant Kaye, the shift supervisor, and relayed what the attorney had said.  
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Kaye Dep. 79:13-23, Exh. F to Grant Decl., ECF 141-2.  Kaye immediately ordered that Claypole 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  be moved to a safety cell and placed on suicide watch.  Id. 82:21-83:3.   Safety cells at the County 
S d nr
ee 17  jail are small cells with padded rubber walls.  They do not contain furniture, mattress, or blanket, 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  and a grate in the floor is used in lieu of a toilet.  Detainees and inmates placed on suicide watch 
19  are clothed in safety smocks.  Kaye personally supervised Claypoleโs placement in a safety cell 
20  and she explained to him that he was being placed in the cell because of his attorneyโs concerns.  
21  Id. 90:13-21.  Kaye or another deputy then advised the jailโs medical staff via radio that someone 
22  had been placed in a safety cell for suicide watch.  Id. 97:20-98:6.  
23    Monterey County contracts with Defendant California Forensic Medical Group (โCFMGโ) 
24  to provide health care at the jail, including mental health treatment.  In the very early hours of 
25  Thursday, May 2, 2013, Nurse Lavina Shene screened Claypole using CFMGโs Nursing 
26 
                                                 
27 
1 As discussed below, there are significant factual disputes with respect to material issues 
unrelated to chronology that preclude summary judgment on most of the claims addressed in these 
28 
motions. 
2 

 
1  Assessment of Psychiatric & Suicidal Inmate form.  Shene noted that Claypole reported a 
2  psychiatric history; had been diagnosed with anxiety, attention deficit disorder, and insomnia; was 
3  under the care of a psychiatrist; and had prescriptions for Klonopin, Seroquel, and Adderal, which 
4  he last had taken two days prior.  Shene noted that Claypole had poor eye contact, was calm, and 
5  had a flat affect.  She identified him as a danger to self on the suicide log and indicated that he was 
6  to remain on suicide watch.   
7    At approximately 5:50 a.m., shortly before the end of her shift, Shene called Defendant 
8  Taylor Fithian, M.D., to inform him that Claypole had been placed on suicide watch.  Defendant 
9  Fithian is the president and co-founder of CFMG.  During the relevant time frame, he was 
10  CFMGโs medical director as well as the psychiatrist and supervisor in charge of all other mental 
11  health staff at the jail.  Fithian was responsible for development of CFMGโs policies and 
12  procedures and the overall day-to-day practice of medicine at the jail. 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13    First Removal from Suicide Watch (Thursday, May 2)   
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    Fithian met with Claypole at approximately 8:35 a.m. on Thursday, May 2, 2013, and 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  discontinued suicide watch at approximately 9:00 a.m.  Claypole remained in the safety cell for 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  some period of time โ exactly how long is disputed by the parties โ before he was transferred to 
S d nr
ee 17  cell A204 in โA-pod.โ  A-pod and B-pod are units consisting of single cells that predominantly are 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  used to house individuals with mental health needs.  Bass Dep. 75:7-79:24, Exh. Vol. 3 to Rifkin 
19  Decl., ECF 147-5.  Other units, including C-pod, are used as overflow housing for individuals 
20  with mental health needs.  Id.  A-pod, B-pod, and C-pod are โlockdownโ units, meaning that 
21  individuals housed there generally are locked in their cells for approximately twenty-three hours a 
22  day and permitted to use the dayroom, take a shower, or do other activities outside the cell for 
23  approximately one hour a day.  Id.  Individuals housed in lockdown units also are permitted to 
24  come out for visits, court or medical appointments, and certain jail events.  Id.  Individuals with 
25  mental health needs are housed in A-pod and B-pod because they are single cells, and thus the 
26  risks of assaults between inmates is lessened.  Id. 75:17-76:3. 
27    The lockdown cells contain beds with sheets.  Bass Dep. 104:21-105:7, Exh. Vol. 3 to 
28  Rifkin Decl., ECF 147-5.  In 2013, when Claypole was housed in A-pod, the lockdown cells had 
3 

 
1  air vents in the walls or ceilings that could be used as attachment points for suicide by hanging.  
2  Id. 105:14-106:15, 110:7-19.  A single deputy is stationed in the corridor to monitor A-pod, B-
3  pod, and C-pod.   Id.  From that station, the deputy can see into all of B-pod but only part of A-
4  pod.  Id. 85:17-87:8.  The deputy cannot see into cell A204, where Claypole was housed, from the 
5  corridor.  Id. 86:25-87:8.  The deputy does hourly welfare and safety checks of the pod cells.  Id. 
6  104:8-20.  Those hourly checks consist of walking through both tiers of each pod and can 
7  completed within one or two minutes.  Id. 90:2-19.  No additional safety checks are performed 
8  when an individual is placed in a lockdown cell upon release from suicide watch.  Id. 104:8-12. 
9    Second Placement on Suicide Watch (Friday, May 3) 
10    Claypole was not seen by mental health personnel again until Friday, May 3, 2013.  On 
11  Friday afternoon, he was visited by Kim Spano, a marriage and family therapist employed by 
12  CFMG.  Spanoโs notes reflect that Claypole was โodd,โ โin a bizarre state,โ โunsettled,โ and 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  โ[a]gitated, upset.โ  Spano Dep. 95:7-14, Exh. I to Grant Decl., ECF 149-1.  Spano felt that 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Claypole was โclearly deludedโ and โclearly psychotic.โ  Id. 101:1-7.  Spano recalls calling 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Defendant Fithian and either speaking to him or leaving him a voicemail message regarding 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Claypoleโs condition.  Id. 101:13-102:4.  Fithian recalls that he and Spano spoke.  Fithian Decl. ยถ 
S d nr
ee 17  6, ECF 152-4.  Fithian and Spano agreed that Claypole should be placed in a safety cell.  Id.  
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Claypole was removed from cell A204 and placed in a safety cell. 
19    When Nurse Shene came on duty the night of May 3, 2013, she reviewed the safety log but 
20  not Spanoโs progress notes, and she checked on Claypole twice during the early morning hours.  
21  Shene Dep. 76:5-78:5, Exh. J to Grant Decl., ECF 149-1.  At the 5:15 a.m. check, Shene spoke to 
22  Claypole and noted that he denied suicidal ideation, he verbally contracted for safety, and he 
23  agreed to let staff know if he felt like he was going to harm himself or others.  Id. 78:4-25.  
24  Claypole also asked to be removed from the safety cell and requested sleeping medication.  Id. 
25  79:6-7.   
26    Second Removal from Suicide Watch (Saturday, May 4) 
27    Shortly after 6:00 a.m. on Saturday, May 4, 2013, Shene called Defendant Fithian and 
28  reported that Claypole had denied suicidal ideation, verbally contracted for safety, said he was 
4 

 
1  really tired, and requested sleep medications.  Shene Dep. 83:21-84:11, Exh. J to Grant Decl., ECF 
2  149-1.  Defendant Fithian, who had not seen Claypole since Thursday, May 2, gave Shene a 
3  verbal order to discontinue suicide watch.  Id. 84:12-14.  Claypole remained in the safety cell for 
4  some period of time โ jail records are unclear as to how long โ and then he was returned to cell 
5  A204 in A-pod.  While conducting a safety and welfare check of A-pod at approximately 2:30 
6  p.m. that afternoon, Deputy Raymond Gordano saw Claypole hanging from a bedsheet affixed to a 
7  metal vent above the toilet/sink area.  Gordano used his radio to call another deputy for help and 
8  then called for medical help.  The deputies cut Claypole down and performed mouth-to-mouth 
9  breathing and chest compressions until medical staff arrived to relieve them.  Claypole died 
10  several days later when he was taken off life support.2 
11    II.  LEGAL STANDARD 
12    โA party is entitled to summary judgment if the โmovant shows that there is no genuine 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  dispute as to any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.โโ  City of 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Pomona v. SQM North America Corp., 750 F.3d 1036, 1049 (9th Cir. 2014) (quoting Fed. R. Civ. 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  P. 56(a)).  โThe moving party initially bears the burden of proving the absence of a genuine issue 
 sir
et

3    โAn officialโs deliberate indifference to a substantial risk of serious harm to an inmate โ

5  fortiori, the Fourteenth Amendment.โ  Conn, 591 F.3d at 1094; see also Gibson, 290 F.3d at 1187 
6  (โpersons in custody have the established right to not have officials remain deliberately indifferent

8    To demonstrate that Kaye was deliberately indifferent in this case, Plaintiffs must show 
9  that (1) Claypole had a serious medical need and (2) Kayeโs officialโs response to the need was

N 18  government may be held liable under ยง 1983 when the individual who committed the 
19  constitutional tort was an official with final policy-making authority or such an official ratified a 
20  subordinateโs unconstitutional decision or action and the basis for it.โ  Id. at 1250 (internal 
21  quotation marks and citation omitted).   
22    Plaintiffs appear to be asserting liability against CFMG based upon its asserted de facto 
23  policy of sending inmates with mental illness to A-pod or B-pod upon release from suicide watch.  
24  Plaintiffs also appear to be asserting that CFMG is liable for the acts of its policy maker, Fithian.   
25 
                                                 
26 
9 Fithian does not argue that, if Claypole was at substantial risk of harm on the morning of May 4, 
2013, Fithian responded adequately by discharging Claypole from suicide watch knowing that he 
27 
would go back to A-pod. 
   
28 
 
25 

 
1        a.  Policy 
2    Plaintiffs present the following evidence in support of their own motion and in opposition 
3  to CFMGโs motion.  They present the opinions of their expert, Dr. Patterson, that Claypoleโs 
4  medical treatment fell below the professional standard of care and that his suicide likely was 
5  foreseeable under the circumstances.  Patterson Report at 191-94, Exh. 117 to Rifkin Decl., ECF 
6  143-9.  While Dr. Patterson does not opine as to the constitutionality of CFMGโs policies, he does 
7  opine that Claypoleโs placement in a lockdown unit was inappropriate and contributed to his 
8  suicide.  Id.  Dr. Pattersonโs opinions could give rise to a reasonable inference that a policy of 
9  transitioning individuals from safety cells directly to lockdown cells without other attendant 
10  precautions amounts to deliberate indifference.10 
11    In opposition to Plaintiffsโ motion and in support of its own motion, CFMG presents the 
12  opinion of its expert, Dr. Hayward, that CFMGโs policies meet minimal professional standards of 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  care and constitutional standards.  See Hayward Report at 11, Exh. B to Bertling Decl., ECF 125; 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Hayward Dep. 54:13-55:19.  Another of CFMGโs experts, Dr. Jason Roof, also opines that 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  CFMGโs policies meet professional standards of care and constitutional standards, and that the 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  care rendered to Claypole was appropriate and within the standard of care.  Roof Report at 17, 
S d nr
ee 17  Exh. B to Bertling Decl., ECF 125.  CFMG also relies upon CFMGโs written Policy and 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Procedure Manual, which incorporates in its Suicide Prevention section Monterey Countyโs 
19  written plan for the prevention of suicide.  The plan specifies that an individual who shows 
20  potential risk of suicide must be referred to medical staff for assessment.  Fithian states in his 
21  declaration that in May 2013, he could have directed that an individual released from suicide 
22  watch be housed in โa variety of step down units.โ11  Fithian Decl. ยถ 11, ECF 152-4.  
23 
                                                 
10 The Medical Defendants assert that Dr. Patterson โhas begrudgingly testified CFMGโs suicide 
24 
prevention program met constitutional standards.โ  Defs.โ Mot. at 6, ECF 124-1.  In support for 
that assertion, Defendants cite to Dr. Pattersonโs report in its entirety and to a page of Dr. 
25 
Pattersonโs deposition that does not support the assertion.  While Dr. Patterson has not opined 
specifically as to the ultimate question of whether CFMGโs policies are constitutionally deficient, 
26 
he has provided expert opinion that may be relied upon by a jury in making that determination. 
 
27 
11 Commander Bass, the Countyโs Rule 30(b)(6) witness, testified that the jail does not have any 
kind of step down cells or transition cells between a safety cell and a regular housing cell.  Bass 
28 
Dep. 103:17-21, Exh. Vol. 3 to Rifkin Decl., ECF 147-5. 
26 

 
1    The partiesโ evidence creates a triable issue of fact as to whether CFMGโs policies were 
2  constitutionally inadequate.     
3        b.  Acts of Dr. Fithian  
4    There is no dispute that Dr. Fithian has final policy-making authority with respect to 
5  CFMG.  As discussed above, Fithianโs deposition testimony and declaration statements create a 
6  triable issue as to whether Fithian knew that transitioning individuals from safety cells to 
7  lockdown cells creates a substantial risk of harm.  To the extent that he may be liable for 
8  deliberate indifference, CFMG may be liable as well.   
9    Accordingly, the partiesโ cross-motions for summary judgment on Claims 1 and 2 are 
10  DENIED as to CFMG. 
11    B.  Claim 3 โ Loss of Parent/Child Relationship 
12    Plaintiffs and the Medical Defendants seek summary judgment on Claim 3 for loss of 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  parent/child relationship.  As noted above, parents may assert a Fourteenth Amendment 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  substantive due process claim if they are deprived of their liberty interest in the companionship of 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  their child through official conduct.  Lemire, 726 F.3d at 1075. โOnly official conduct that shocks 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  the conscience is cognizable as a due process violation.โ  Id. (internal quotation marks and citation 
S d nr
ee 17  omitted).  โA prison officialโs deliberately indifferent conduct will generally shock the conscience 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  so as long as the prison official had time to deliberate before acting or failing to act in a 
19  deliberately indifferent manner.โ  Id. (internal quotation marks and citation omitted).   
20    Claim 3 is based on the Medical Defendantsโ alleged deliberate indifference to Claypoleโs 
21  serious medical needs and thus, for purposes of the present motions, rises or falls with Claims 1 
22  and 2.  Based upon the foregoing discussion, the partiesโ cross-motions for summary judgment on 
23  Claim 3 are DENIED. 
24    C.  Claim 4 โ Medical Malpractice 
25    Only Plaintiffs seek summary judgment on Claim 4, alleging medical malpractice.  Fithian 
26  and CFMG do not seek summary judgment on this claim.   
27 
                                                                                                                                                                
28 
 
27 

 
1    โThe elements of a cause of action for medical malpractice are:  (1) a duty to use such 
2  skill, prudence, and diligence as other members of the profession commonly possess and exercise; 
3  (2) a breach of the duty; (3) a proximate causal connection between the negligent conduct and the 
4  injury; and (4) resulting loss or damage.โ  Chakalis v. Elevator Solutions, Inc., 205 Cal. App. 4th 
5  1557, 1571 (2012) (internal quotation marks and citation omitted).   
6    In support of their motion, Plaintiffs present the opinion of their expert that the medical 
7  treatment provided to Claypole fell below the standard of care.  See Patterson Report at 7, Exh. 
8  117 to Rifkin Decl., ECF 143-9.  This evidence is sufficient to meet Plaintiffsโ initial burden.  
9  However, in opposition to the motion, the Medical Defendants present expert opinion that the 
10  medical treatment provided to Claypole met the standard of care.  See Hayward Report at 16, Exh. 
11  B to Bertling Decl., ECF 125; Roof Report at 17, Exh. B to Bertling Decl., ECF 125.  Given these 
12  competing expert opinions, a triable issue of material fact exists as to the question of breach of the 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  duty of care. 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    Plaintiffsโ motion for summary judgment on Claim 4 is DENIED. 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15    D.  Claim 5 โ Failure to Summon Medical Care 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16    Fithian and CFMG seek summary judgment on Claim 5 for failure to summon medical 
S d nr
ee 17  care.  Plaintiffs do not seek summary judgment on this claim.   
th
intr
Uo
N 18    As discussed above, California Government Code ยง 845.6 provides that a public employee 
19  may be liable for failure to respond to a prisonerโs need for immediate medical care.  Cal. Govโt 
20  Code ยง 845.6; Watson, 21 Cal. App. 4th at 841.  Plaintiffs have not identified a moment when 
21  Fithian and CFMG failed to respond to Claypoleโs need for immediate medical care.  Moreover, it 
22  simply makes no sense for Plaintiffs to assert liability against the Medical Defendants for failing 
23  to summon themselves.  Plaintiffs have submitted no evidence to support the need to summon an 
24  ambulance or other emergency medical service. 
25    The Medical Defendantsโ motion for summary judgment on Claim 5 is GRANTED.    
26    E.  Claim 7 โ Wrongful Death 
27    Only Plaintiffs seek summary judgment on Claim 7, for wrongful death.  Fithian and 
28  CFMG do not seek judgment on this claim.    
28 

 
1    The elements of a wrongful death claim are:  (1) a wrongful act or neglect that (2) causes 
2  (3) the death of another person.  See Cal. Civ. P. Code ยง 377.60; Norgart, 21 Cal. 4th at 390.  In 
3  support of their motion, Plaintiffs submit their expertโs opinion that the medical treatment 
4  provided to Claypole fell below the standard of care.  See Pls.โ Br. at 34, ECF 142.  This evidence 
5  is sufficient to meet Plaintiffsโ initial burden.  However, Fithian and CFMG have submitted 
6  conflicting expert opinions stating that the medical treatment provided to Claypole met the 
7  standard of care.  See Hayward Report at 16, Exh. B to Bertling Decl., ECF 125; Roof Report at 
8  17, Exh. B to Bertling Decl., ECF 125.  Thus a triable issue of material fact exists as to an 
9  essential element of Plaintiffsโ wrongful death claim. 
10    Plaintiffsโ motion for summary judgment on Claim 7 is DENIED. 
11    V.  ORDER 
12    For the foregoing reasons, IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that:

i
rts fo
iD tc 15      motion against the County Defendants is DENIED; and

et
tatsiD 16    (2)  The Medical Defendantsโ motion is GRANTED IN PART as to Claim 5 and  
S d nr
